top_categories.workout_context: 3Rides Aachen's German mountains, Mountain gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 65 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic 3Rides Aachen's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before July.
69ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At 3Rides Aachen, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of 3Rides Aachen. Train it until it feels boring.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At 3Rides Aachen, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
When someone attacks on german mountain gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
65 miles on german mountain gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Varied gradients on german mountain gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on german mountain gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Smooth pedaling at 65 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for 3Rides Aachen’s 65 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at 3Rides Aachen requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on german mountain gravel to build confidence. Expect: german mountains, mountain gravel, regional event.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 65 miles of german mountain gravel in Winterberg/Aachen, Germany.
